security_audit.summary: Pure Markdown documentation skill containing TDD guidelines and error recording protocols. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or filesystem access. This is a policy document for AI agent behavior enforcement. All 56 static findings are false positives triggered by documentation patterns (Markdown backticks, relative links, hash metadata fields).

content.value_statement: AI coding workflows often skip tests or write them after code, leading to untested functionality and hidden bugs. This skill enforces the TDD Iron Law: no production code until a failing test exists. It provides enforcement checkpoints, error recording protocols, and rationalization prevention to ensure every feature has proper test coverage.
actual_capabilities: Enforces TDD Iron Law: no production code without failing test first
Validates test execution with checkpoint verification
Provides error recording protocol for test failures
Prevents rationalization and shortcuts during development
Documents test quality requirements for good tests
Integrates with flow-dev phases for TDD workflow
limitations: Enforces discipline but cannot automatically run test commands
Requires user to execute test commands manually or via other tools
Cannot prevent code from being written in editor outside AI context
Does not generate test code automatically

use_cases.title: Maintain Test Coverage
use_cases.description: Enforce TDD discipline in AI-assisted coding to ensure every feature has failing test before implementation

use_cases.title: Validate Test Quality
use_cases.description: Use checkpoint system to verify tests fail before code and pass after implementation

use_cases.title: Embed TDD Workflows
use_cases.description: Integrate TDD enforcement into AI coding agents for consistent test-first development

prompt_templates.title: Start New Feature
prompt_templates.prompt: Use flow-tdd to implement this feature. Start by writing failing tests that define the expected behavior before any production code.

prompt_templates.title: Verify Tests Fail
prompt_templates.prompt: flow-tdd: Run tests to confirm new tests fail. Do not proceed until all new tests fail with expected errors.

prompt_templates.title: Implement Minimal Code
prompt_templates.prompt: flow-tdd: Implement minimal code to make the failing tests pass. No extra features. One test at a time.

prompt_templates.title: Record Errors
prompt_templates.prompt: flow-tdd: Record this test failure in ERROR_LOG.md with timestamp, phase, error type, root cause, and resolution.

best_practices: Always run tests after writing them to confirm they fail before implementation
Write only enough code to pass the current failing test, avoid speculative features
Record every test failure and its resolution in ERROR_LOG.md for future reference
anti_patterns: Writing production code before tests - violates TDD Iron Law
Tests that pass immediately - proves nothing and indicates invalid test
Keeping exploration code without tests - delete and restart with TDD

faq.question: Does this skill run tests automatically?
faq.answer: No. The skill enforces TDD discipline and provides protocols. You must execute test commands via your terminal or test runner.

faq.question: What happens if tests pass immediately?
faq.answer: This is a red flag. Passing tests immediately mean either the test is invalid or code already exists. Delete the code and restart with tests first.

faq.question: Can I skip tests for simple code?
faq.answer: No. Simple code breaks. The TDD Iron Law has no exceptions. All production code requires failing tests first.

faq.question: How does this integrate with Claude Code?
faq.answer: The skill provides prompts and workflows that can be invoked when asking Claude Code to implement features. It works with any AI coding tool.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. This is a documentation-only skill. It does not access files, networks, or execute code. It only provides guidelines and protocols.

faq.question: How is this different from other testing tools?
faq.answer: This skill enforces workflow discipline rather than running tests. It complements test runners by ensuring tests are written first and quality requirements are met.
